10117 Berlin - Germany }} The ''German'' '''Socio-Economic Panel''' (SOEP [{{IPA|/'zœp/}}], for ''Sozio-oekonomisches Panel'') is a [[Longitudinal study|longitudinal]] [[panel data]]set of the population in [[Germany]]. It is a [[household]] based study which started in 1984 and which reinterviews adult household members annually. Additional samples have been taken of East Germans (from 1990, coincident with [[German reunification|reunification]]) and immigrants (in 1994) as well as in 1998, 2000, 2002 and 2006. In 2007, there will be about 12,000 households, and more than 20,000 adult persons sampled. Some of the many topics surveyed include household composition, occupation, employment, earnings, health and [[life satisfaction]]. The annual surveys are conducted by the [[German Institute for Economic Research]] (DIW Berlin) and the [[Kantar Group]]. The survey is funded by the German Federal Government and the State of Berlin via the «Bund-Länder-Kommission» (State/Federal State Commission) for Educational Planning and Research Promotion.[http://www.diw.de/en/diw_02.c.299771.en/about_soep.html#299803 SOEP-Overview/Organization & Financing] (URL accessed 2013-05-28) Data are available to [[social science]] researchers in Germany and abroad in [[SPSS]]/[[PSPP]], [[SAS System|SAS]]/[[DAP (software)|DAP]], [[Stata]], [[R (programming language)|R]]/[[S-PLUS]] and [[ASCII]] format. Extensive documentation in English and German is available online. SOEP data are integrated into the [[Cross National Equivalent File]] (CNEF) which contains panel data from Australia, Canada, Germany, Great Britain and the United States. The data distribution of the SOEP for researchers outside of Germany is supplied with the CNEF by a group at [[Cornell University]]. Application to use this international distribution has to be made to the [[German Institute for Economic Research|DIW Berlin]]. == Subsamples == {| class="wikitable" ! colspan=2 | Sample ! Start-Year ! Households ! Persons ! Description |- | style="border-right: none;/*vertical-align: top;*/"| '''A''' | style="border-left: none" | West-German (residents) | 1984 | n=4,528 | rowspan=2 | n=12,245 | Head is either German or other nationality than those in Sample B |- | style="border-right: none"| '''B''' | style="border-left: none" | Foreigners | 1984 | n=1,393 | Head is either [[Turkish people|Turkish]], [[Italian people|Italian]], [[Spanish people|Spanish]], [[Greek people|Greek]] or from the [[former Yugoslavia]] |- | colspan=6 align="center"| [[German reunification]] |- | style="border-right: none"| '''C''' | style="border-left: none" | East-Germans | 1990 | n=2,179 | n=4,453 | Head was a citizen of the [[East Germany|GDR]] (expansion of survey territory) |- | style="border-right: none"| '''D''' | style="border-left: none" | Immigrants | 1994/1995 | n=522 | n=1,078 | At least one household member has moved to Germany after 1989 (expansion of survey population) |- | style="border-right: none"| '''E''' | style="border-left: none" | Refreshment | 1998 | n=1,067 | n=1,923 | Random sample covering all existing subsamples (total population) |- | style="border-right: none"| '''F''' | style="border-left: none" | Innovation | 2000 | n=6,052 | n=10,890 | Random sample covering all existing subsamples (total population) |- | style="border-right: none"| '''G''' | style="border-left: none" | High Income | 2002 | n=1,224 | n=2,671 | Monthly net household income is more than 4.500 [[Euro]] (7.500 [[German mark|DM]]) |- | style="border-right: none"| '''H''' | style="border-left: none" | Refreshment | 2006 | n=1,506 | n=2,616 | Random sample covering all existing subsamples (total population) |- | style="border-right: none"| '''I''' | style="border-left: none" | Incentive/Refreshment | 2009 | n=1,531 | n=2,509 | Random sample covering all existing subsamples (total population). Since 2011 it is no longer a part of the SOEP Core study. It is now a part of the new SOEP Innovation Study.[http://www.diw.de/en/diw_01.c.390424.en/soep_innovation_sample_soep_is.html SOEP Innovation Study] (URL accessed 2013-05-28) |- | style="border-right: none"| '''J''' | style="border-left: none" | Refreshment | 2011 | n=3.136 | n=5.161 | Random sample covering all existing subsamples (total population) |+ SOEP Subsamples 2011[http://panel.gsoep.de/soepinfo2011/info/soep_samples_size.pdf SOEP Samples Overview - 2011 / Wave 28] (Nov. 2012) (URL accessed 2013-05-28) |} ==See also== *[[Canadian Survey of Labour and Income Dynamics]] (SLID) *[[Household, Income and Labour Dynamics in Australia Survey]] (HILDA) *[[Panel Study of Income Dynamics]] (PSID) *[[Swiss Household Panel]] (SHP) [http://www.swisspanel.ch/?lang=en|(URL:last access 2013-05-28)] *[[LISS panel]] (LISS) * [[Survey on Household Income and Wealth]] (SHIW) *[[UK households: a longitudinal study]] (UKHLS) / Understanding Society, UK ** formerly [[British Household Panel Survey]] (BHPS), UK == Notes == ==External links== *[http://www.diw.de/en/soep SOEP (official) website] (URL accessed 2013-05-28) *[https://cnef.ehe.osu.edu Cross National Equivalent File (CNEF)] (URL accessed 2016-01-28) *[http://www.swisspanel.ch/index.php?lang=en Swiss Household Panel] (URL accessed 2013-05-28) *[http://www.lissdata.nl LISS panel] (URL accessed 2013-05-28) {{coord|52|30|44|N|13|23|19.32|E|region:DE-BE_type:landmark|display=title}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Economy of Germany]] [[Category:Economic data]] [[Category:Panel data]] [[Category:Cohort studies]] [[Category:Leibniz Association]] [[Category:Household surveys]]

{{multiple issues| {{tone|date=September 2014}} {{refimprove|date=September 2014}} {{COI|date=September 2014}} }} {{Infobox book | name = The Future of Oil: A Straight Story of the Canadian Oil Sands | image = Future of Oil Cover Page.jpg | caption = | author = [[Sanjay Patel (filmmaker)|Sanjay Patel]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = [[Canada]] | language = [[English language|English]] | series = | subject = | genre = | publisher = [http://www.creativentures.in/ CreatiVentures] | pub_date = November 2012 | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = 248 | isbn = 9788188360192 | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The Future of Oil: A Straight Story of the Canadian Oil Sands''''' is a 2012 book by the Canadian engineer, writer<ref name="OGM1">[http://www.theogm.com/2013/06/04/image-and-reality-tailings-ponds/ Patel, Sanjay; The Image & Reality: Tailings Pond (June 4, 2013); The Oil & Gas Magazine. Retrieved 2013-09-08.].</ref><ref name="OGM2">[http://www.theogm.com/2013/04/04/ghg-emissions-canadian-oil-sands-industry/ Patel, Sanjay; GHG Emissions: Canadian Oil Sands industry (April 4, 2013); The Oil & Gas Magazine. Retrieved 2013-09-08.].</ref><ref name="OGM3">[http://www.theogm.com/2012/12/08/canadian-oilsands-what-where-and-how/ Patel, Sanjay; Canadian Oil Sands: What, Where & How (Dec 8, 2012); The Oil & Gas Magazine. Retrieved 2013-09-08.].</ref><ref name="HPM1">[http://www.hydrocarbonprocessing.com/Article/2598239/Canadian-oil-sands-Opportunities-technologies-and-challenges.html Patel, Sanjay; "The Canadian Oil Sands: Opportunities, technologies and challenges", (Feb 5, 2007); Hydrocarbon Processing Magazine. Retrieved 2013-09-08.].</ref> and [[oil sands]] manager Sanjay K. Patel that identifies and responds to a pressing concern of many: without increasing oil supply, the future is bleak and there is a risk of high oil prices. Patel works for [[Suncor Energy|Suncor Energy Inc.]]<ref>[http://www.futureofoil.ca "The Future of Oil"]</ref>
==Summary== The book starts with the argument that objective considerations of economic necessity, along with the nature of current technological limitations, should lead us to a series of connected and inescapable conclusions. According to the author, transition to an age of cleaner energy production is necessary and inevitable, but we cannot yet live without oil; oil must have a future, or we do not have one. He adds that since conventional oil reserves are dwindling, we really have no alternative: we need to increasingly rely on [[unconventional oil]] to complement them, and oil from the [[Athabasca oil sands|Canadian oil sands]] is the best unconventional oil we can get.
The book covers the history and technology of Canadian oil sands and pertinent issues related to the economy, environment and ethics. Patel has made a case for the oil sands, but at the same time has also addressed the main drawbacks of extracting and using this oil.
In other words, the book objectively presents the arguments of both oil sands critics and proponents and presents all the main objections to oil sands development posed by journalists, environmentalists, first Nations leaders, and others. As a result, the reader should gain a better understanding of the issues involved, and be able to form their opinion about Canada’s oil sands.
==Media Response== On the book's release in November 2012, it sparked significant interest in the media{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} and the author appeared in various interviews including popular television and radio shows in Canada.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} Immediately after its release, the author appeared in more than 20 media interviews including the following: *[http://calgary.ctvnews.ca/video?clipId=820291&playlistId=1.1066707&binId=1.820591 CTV Morning Live Calgary] *The Rutherford Show 770 CHQR *CBC Radio British Columbia – Early Edition with Rick Cluff *CTV Noon News Edmonton *[http://www.cbc.ca/player/Radio/Local+Shows/Alberta/ID/2312959771/ CBC Radio - Alberta at Noon with Host Donna McElligott ] *Global News Edmonton *[http://video.citytv.com/video/detail/2011059786001.000000/the-future-of-oil/ CityTV Breakfast Television Edmonton ] *Alberta Primetime- CTV2 Edmonton *660 News with Kevin Usselman Calgary *The Rob Breakenridge Show on the Corus Radio Network *Dave Cooper, [[Edmonton Journal]].<ref name="edmonton journal">[http://www2.canada.com/edmontonjournal/news/business/story.html?id=d4bda3ab-b69c-4d07-a29e-399b298bb3b2 Cooper, Dave (December 26, 2012). "A Champion for the oil sands”. Edmonton Journal. Retrieved 2013-09-08],.</ref> *Frank Peebles, Prince George Citizen.<ref name="PGC">[http://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/article/20130104/princegeorge0101/301049978/-1/princegeorge/author-defends-oilsands-development Peebles, Frank(January 4, 2013). "Author defends oil sands development". Prince George Citizen. Retrieved 2013-09-08],.</ref> *Vincent McDermott, Fort McMurray Today.<ref name="FMT">[http://www.fortmcmurraytoday.com/2012/12/02/local-profile-engineer-pens-book-about-oil McDermott, Vincent (December 2, 2012). “Engineer pens book about oil”. Fort McMurray Today. Retrieved 2013-09-08],.</ref> *Oil sands review magazine by Deborah Jeremko *[http://www.theoilandgasweek.com/030413/subint1.html Clean sands (2013); The Oil & Gas Week. Retrieved 2013-09-08 ]
==External links== *{{url|http://www.futureofoil.ca}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2016}} {{SSM}}{{LGBT rights}} This page contains a timeline of significant events regarding [[same-sex marriage]] and legal recognition of same-sex couples worldwide. It begins with the history of same-sex unions during ancient times, which consisted of unions ranging from informal and temporary relationships to highly ritualized unions, and continues to modern-day [[Marriage law#State recognition|state-recognized]] same-sex marriage. Events concerning same-sex marriages becoming legal in a country or in a country's state are listed in '''bold'''. <!--{{TOCyears|startyear=1970|endyear=2017}}--> {{horizontal TOC|nonum=yes}}
==Ancient times== {{Main article|History of same-sex unions}} Various types of same-sex marriages have existed,<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1ha9GgWNmy0C&pg=PT267 |title=The Origins and Role of Same-Sex Relations In Human Societies – James Neill – Google Boeken |publisher=Google Books |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> ranging from informal, unsanctioned relationships to highly ritualized unions.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mlFp0nFhvbwC&dq=Ritualized+Homosexuality+Herdt&printsec=frontcover&source=bn&hl=en&ei=MBbOSvmjIIOa8Aao5PT6Aw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4#v=onepage&q=&f=false |title=Ritualized Homosexuality in Melanesia |publisher=Google Books |date=28 January 1993 |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref>
[[Cicero]] mentions the marriage (using the Latin verb for "to marry", i.e. nubere) of the son of Curio the Elder, but he does it in a metaphorical form to criticize his enemy Antonius. Cicero states thus that the younger Curio was "united in a stable and permanent marriage" to Antonius.<ref>Cicero ''Philippic'' 18 February, 2.45 See old translation at: http://old.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.02.0021&layout=&loc=18 February, 2.45</ref> Martial also mentions a number of same-sex marriages, but always in derisory terms against people whom he wants to mock.<ref>Martial 12.42, 1.35, 3.93, 12.95. Old Translations of passages at: http://www.tertullian.org/fathers/martial_epigrams_book12.htm http://www.tertullian.org/fathers/martial_epigrams_book01.htm http://www.tertullian.org/fathers/martial_epigrams_book03.htm</ref>
Practices and [[rituals]] for [[same sex unions]] were more recognized in Mesopotamia than in [[ancient Egypt]].<ref>Martial, 465</ref> In ancient [[Assyria]], there was considered to be nothing wrong with homosexual love between men.<ref>Martial, 468.</ref><ref>Gay Rights Or Wrongs: A Christian's Guide to Homosexual Issues and Ministry, by Mike Mazzalonga, 1996, p.11</ref><ref name="Homosexuality, Erik Holland page 334">The Nature Of Homosexuality, Erik Holland, page 334, 2004</ref><ref name="Homosexuality, Erik Holland page 334"/> The Almanac of Incantations contained prayers giving [[equality before the law|equal standing]] to the love of a man for both a woman and a man.<ref>Bullough, p. 53</ref>
At least two of the Roman Emperors were in same-sex unions; and in fact, thirteen out of the first fourteen Roman Emperors held to be bisexual or exclusively homosexual.<ref>Hinsch, Bret. (1990). ''Passions of the Cut Sleeve''. University of California Press. pp. 35–36.</ref> The first Roman emperor to have married a man was [[Nero]], who is reported to have married two other men on different occasions. First with one of his [[freedman|freedmen]], [[Pythagoras (freedman)|Pythagoras]], to whom Nero took the role of the bride, and later as a groom Nero married a young boy, who resembled one of his concubines,<ref>Nero missed her so greatly after her death that on learning of a woman who resembled her he at first sent for her and kept her; but later he caused a boy of the freedmen, whom he used to call Sporus,..."he formally "married" Sporus, and assigned the boy a regular dowry according to contract;" q.v., Suetonius ''Nero'' 28; Dio Cassius '' Epitome '' 62.28 Old Translation of passage at: http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Cassius_Dio/62*.html </ref> named [[Sporus]].
Adolescent emperor [[Elagabalus]] referred to his [[quadriga|chariot]] driver, a blond slave from [[Caria]] named [[Hierocles (charioteer)|Hierocles]], as his husband.<ref name="dio-history-lxxix-30">Cassius Dio, ''Roman History'' [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Cassius_Dio/79*.html#78-30 LXXIX.30]</ref> He also married an athlete named Zoticus in a lavish public ceremony in Rome amidst the rejoicings of the citizens.<ref>Dio Cassius '' Epitome '' 80.5, 80.14, 80.15, 80.16; Herodian ''Roman History '' 5.6.1–5.6.2
Old Translation of passage at: http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Cassius_Dio/80*.html http://www.tertullian.org/fathers/herodian_05_book5.htm </ref>
These same-sex marriages continued until Christianity became the official religion of the Roman Empire. A law in the [[Theodosian Code]] (''C. Th.'' 9.7.3) was issued in 342 AD by the Christian emperors Constantius II and Constans. This law prohibited [[Homosexuality in ancient Rome|same-sex marriage in ancient Rome]] and ordered that those who were so married were to be executed.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xOmU5q1x8HsC&pg=PA272 |title=Wrestling With God And Men: Homosexuality In The Jewish Tradition – Steven Greenberg – Google Boeken |publisher=Google Books |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5LXpN4oaOwAC&pg=PA123 |title=Christianity, Social Tolerance, and Homosexuality: Gay People in Western ... – John Boswell – Google Boeken |publisher=Google Books |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref>
In the Middle Ages, a same-sex marriage between the two men Pedro Díaz and Muño Vandilaz in the [[Galicia (Spain)|Galician]] municipality of [[Rairiz de Veiga]] in Spain occurred on 16 April 1061. They were married by a priest at a small chapel. The historic documents about the church wedding were found at [[Monastery of San Salvador de Celanova]].<ref name="firstmarriage">{{cite web |url=http://www.galiciae.com/nova/78210.html |language=gl |author=Carlos Callón |title=Callón gaña o Vicente Risco de Ciencias Sociais cun ensaio sobre a homosexualidade na Idade Media |accessdate=1 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110305024907/http://www.galiciae.com/nova/78210.html |archivedate=5 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The [[Siwa Oasis]] in [[Egypt]] had an historical acceptance of male homosexuality and even rituals of [[same-sex marriage]] — traditions that Egyptian authorities have sought to repress, with increasing success, since the [[early 20th century]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Dumairy|first=A.|title=Siwa Past and Present|year=2005|location=Alexandria}}</ref> The German [[egyptologist]] George Steindorff explored the [[oasis]] in 1900 and reported that homosexual relations were common and often extended to a form of marriage.<ref>{{cite book|last=Steindorff|first=George|title=Durch die Libysche Wuste Zur Amonoase|year=1904|page=111|publisher=Velohgen and Klasing|location=Leipsig}}</ref>
==1970s==
===1970=== * On 18 May 1970, two [[University of Minnesota]] students, Richard John Jack Baker and James Michael McConnell, applied to Hennepin County District Court clerk Gerald Nelson for a marriage license. He denied the application, because the applicants were both men. Baker and McConnell sued Nelson, claiming Minnesota law on marriage made no mention of gender. The trial court was not impressed with the argument, agreeing with Nelson. The state Supreme Court agreed with the lower court. When Baker and McConnell went to the Minnesota Supreme Court, the court rejected their lawsuit in ''[[Baker v. Nelson]]''.
===1972=== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:McConnell (l) and Baker (r) apply for marriage license 19700518.png|thumb|right|Michael McConnell (l) and Jack Baker apply at the Hennepin County courthouse for a license to marry.]] --> * 15 October: The [[Supreme Court of Minnesota|Supreme Court]] of the U.S. state of [[Same-sex marriage in Minnesota|Minnesota]] upholds the decision of a lower court that denying a marriage license to a same-sex couple does not violate the U.S. Constitution."<ref name="denniston1">{{cite news|last=Denniston|first=Lyle|title=Gay marriage and ''Baker v. Nelson''|url=http://www.scotusblog.com/2012/07/gay-marriage-and-baker-v-nelson/|accessdate=18 October 2012|newspaper=SCOTUSblog|date=4 July 2012}}</ref> The lawsuit originated in a marriage application filed by activist [[Jack Baker (activist)|Jack Baker]] and Michael McConnell in 1970. An appeal of that decision ended when the U.S. Supreme Court declined to review it "for want of a substantial federal question".<ref name="denniston1"/> (see ''[[Baker v. Nelson]]'').
===1973=== * 1 January: [[Maryland]] becomes the first state in the U.S. to statutorily ban same-sex marriage.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mlis.state.md.us/asp/statutes_respond.asp?article=gfl&section=2-201&Extension=HTML |title=MGA HTML Statutes |publisher=Mlis.state.md.us |accessdate=26 July 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120514144358/http://mlis.state.md.us/asp/statutes_respond.asp?article=gfl&section=2-201&Extension=HTML |archive-date=14 May 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In the following two decades, other states joined Maryland in statutorily banning same-sex marriage, reaching almost the totality of US states by 1994.
===1974=== * 20 May: ''Singer v. Hara'', a lawsuit filed by [[Faygele Ben-Miriam|John F. Singer]] and [[Paul Barwick]] after being refused a request for a marriage license at the King County Administration Building in [[Seattle, Washington]] on 20 September 1971, ends with a unanimous rejection by the [[Washington State Court of Appeals]].<ref name="ESanders2">{{cite web|url = http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/Content?oid=45213| title = Marriage Denied| author = Eli Sanders|work= [[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]]|date = 20 October 2005}}</ref>
===1975=== * 26 March: Boulder County clerk Clela Rorex issues first U.S. same-sex marriage license. During the following month, she issued five more same-sex marriage licenses. Boulder District Attorney deferred the licenses, which became void. The matter never reached the courts.<ref name="Davide1">{{cite web|url = http://www.dailykos.com/story/2011/06/24/988562/-Clela-Rorex-Gay-marriage-pioneer| title = Clela Rorex: Gay marriage pioneer| date = 24 June 2011}}</ref><ref name="Davide2">{{cite web|url = http://www.dailycamera.com/ci_23065453/boulder-civil-union-event-adds-layer-living-history| title = Boulder civil union event adds layer of living history, with former clerk Rorex to attend| date = 19 April 2013}}</ref><ref name="Davide3">{{cite web|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XOs7Kwhz16w| title = Clela Rorex: 1975 Same-Sex Marriage license | date = 9 July 2013}}</ref>
===1979=== * June: The [[Same-sex marriage in the Netherlands|Netherlands]] adopts an "Unregistered Cohabitation" scheme as a civil status in rent law, becoming the first country in the world where same-sex couples could apply for limited rights.<ref name="N"/>
==1980s== ===1982=== * May: [[San Francisco]] [[San Francisco Board of Supervisors|Board of Supervisors]] passes [[Harry Britt]]'s measure to extend health insurance coverage to same-sex domestic partners of public employees, largely because of the reaction to the early days of [[AIDS]], but does not provide for a registry available to the general public. Mayor [[Dianne Feinstein]] vetoes the measure.<ref>Bishop, Katherine. "[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?sec=health&res=950DEFD9163DF932A05756C0A96F948260 San Francisco Grants Recognition to Couples Who Aren't Married]," ''New York Times'' 31 May 1989.</ref>
===1984=== * December: [[Berkeley, California|Berkeley]] becomes the first city to pass a domestic partner policy for city and school district employees after a year of work by the Domestic Partner Task Force chaired by Leland Traiman. Working with the Task Force is [[Tom Brougham]], a Berkeley city employee who coined the term "domestic partner" and created the concept. All other domestic partner policies in California and elsewhere are patterned after Berkeley's.
===1985=== * February 21: [[West Hollywood, California|West Hollywood]] becomes the first US city to enact a domestic partnership registry open to all citizens<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1985-02-28/news/we-13043_1_domestic-partnership-law|title=Law Lists Rights, Lacks Teeth : Intent of W. Hollywood Domestic Partnership Ordinance Clear but Impact Isn't|first=STEPHEN|last=BRAUN|date=28 February 1985|publisher=|via=LA Times}}</ref>.
===1989=== * May 30: [[San Francisco]] [[San Francisco Board of Supervisors|Board of Supervisors]] passes a domestic partnership registry ordinance, which is closely defeated by San Francisco voters as Proposition S on November 7. * 1 October: [[Same-sex marriage in Denmark|Denmark]] becomes the first country in the world to legally recognise [[Civil unions in Denmark|same-sex unions]], after passing a bill legalising "registered partnerships" in a 71–47 vote.<ref>{{Cite news | title= Governments that have recognized same-sex relationships |url=http://www.religioustolerance.org/hom_mar4.htm |publisher=Religious Tolerance |accessdate=9 September 2009}}</ref>
==1990s== ===1990=== * A modified domestic partnership registry ordinance is passed by the [[San Francisco]] [[San Francisco Board of Supervisors|Board of Supervisors]], and the ordinance is ratified by voters as Proposition K on November 6.
===1991=== * [[California]] Assemblyman [[John L. Burton]], D-San Francisco, proposed [[Assembly Bill 167]] that would have changed the state civil marriage code to permit [[same-sex marriages]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Tremblay|first1=J.P.|title=Homosexual anti-bias, marriage bills sure to cause a stir|url=http://www.unmarriedamerica.org/Archives/1972-2005-TFC-News-Stories/1991-Sacramento-Job-and-Marriage-Bills.pdf|website=Unmarried America.org|publisher=The Sacramento Union|accessdate=26 June 2015}}</ref> * June: Berkeley becomes the third city in California to create a domestic partnership registry for same- and opposite-sex couples.
===1993=== * 30 April: [[Norway]] approves a registered partnerships bill, becoming the second country in the world (after [[Denmark]]) to provide legal recognition for same-sex couples. It came into effect on 1 August. * 5 May: The [[Supreme Court of Hawaii|Supreme Court]] of the U.S. state of [[Same-sex marriage in Hawaii|Hawaii]] rules in ''[[Baehr v. Miike|Baehr v. Lewin]]'' that the Hawaii state statute limiting marriage to opposite-sex couples is presumed to be unconstitutional unless the state can present a "compelling state interest" justifying the same-sex marriage ban.
===1994=== * 23 June: The Parliament of [[Same-sex marriage in Sweden|Sweden]] approves a registered partnerships bill in a 171–141 vote.<ref>{{Cite news |first1=Petar|last1=Sarcevic| first2=Paul|last2=Volken| title= Yearbook of Private International Law |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F_xWIVrDLrwC&pg=PA193&lpg=PA193&dq=sweden+registered+partnership+1994&source=bl&ots=iPPZShbDC7&sig=0paSflwmxRKCS9yurbYoj5G3jPc&hl=en&ei=eFE4StCMFMSHtgf99KnVDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5#v=onepage&q=sweden%20registered%20partnership%201994&f=false |publisher=Google Books |accessdate=9 September 2009}}</ref> It became legal on 1 January 1995.
===1995=== * 12 March : One recorded case of a [[Same-sex marriage in Cambodia|legally valid same-sex civil marriage]] contraction in [[Cambodia]]: Khav Sokha and Pum Eth were married in the village of Kro Bao Ach Kok, in [[Kandal Province]].
===1996=== * 26 April: [[Greenland]] adopts Denmark's [[Civil union|registered partnership]] law.<ref>Yuval Merin, [https://books.google.com/books?id=10rBoQPazt0C&pg=PA67&dq=danish+registered+partnership+act+on+april+26,+1996,+Greenland&hl=es&sa=X&ei=FCBST9vAKcaUtweNg6XDDQ&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=danish%20registered%20partnership%20act%20on%20april%2026%2C%201996%2C%20Greenland&f=false ''Equality for same-sex couples''.] Published in 2002.</ref> * June: The Parliament of [[Same-sex marriage in Iceland|Iceland]] legalizes registered partnerships in a 44–1 vote.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.france.qrd.org/texts/partnership/is/iceland-bill.html |title=Iceland : Recognized partnership law, 1996 |publisher=France.qrd.org |date=1 July 1996 |accessdate=16 July 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160112010241/http://www.france.qrd.org/texts/partnership/is/iceland-bill.html |archive-date=12 January 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Jensen|first=Steffen|title=Partnership law in Iceland|url=http://www.france.qrd.org/assocs/ilga/euroletter/42.html#Iceland|publisher=ILGA Euroletter|date=June 1996|accessdate=9 September 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160112010241/http://www.france.qrd.org/assocs/ilga/euroletter/42.html#Iceland|archive-date=12 January 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * 21 September: President [[Bill Clinton]] of the United States signs the [[Defense of Marriage Act]] into law, which bans the federal Government from recognizing same-sex unions.<ref>''MetroWeekly'': [http://www.metroweekly.com/feature/?ak=6613 Chris Geidner, "Becoming Law," September 29, 2011], accessed 3 March 2012</ref>
===1997=== * 5 July: The [[same-sex marriage in the Netherlands|Netherlands]] passes a registered partnerships bill.<ref name="Doc125TheNetherlands">{{cite web|url=http://www-same-sex.ined.fr/pdf/DocTrav125/05Doc125TheNetherlands.pdf |title=Major legal consequences of marriage, cohabitation and registered partnership for different-sex and same-sex partners in the Netherlands |format=PDF |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> It became law on 1 January 1998.<ref name="N">{{cite web|url=https://same-sex.web.ined.fr/pdf/DocTrav125/05Doc125TheNetherlands.pdf |title=Major legal consequences of marriage, cohabitation and registered partnership for different-sex and same-sex partners in the Netherlands |format=PDF |accessdate=26 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303172043/https://same-sex.web.ined.fr/pdf/DocTrav125/05Doc125TheNetherlands.pdf |archivedate=3 March 2016 |df=dmy }}</ref>
===1998=== * 30 June: [[Catalonia]] becomes the first region of [[LGBT rights in Spain|Spain]] to legalize civil unions for same-sex couples.<ref>{{es icon}} [[El Pais]]. ''[http://elpais.com/diario/1998/07/01/catalunya/899255239_850215.html Cataluña aprueba la primera ley de España que regula las parejas de hecho]''. Retrieved 3 July 2015.</ref> * 3 November: [[Hawaii]] and [[Alaska]] become the first U.S. states to pass constitutional amendments against same-sex marriage.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.law.duke.edu/shell/cite.pl?16%20Alaska%20L.%20Rev.%20213 |title=The Alaska Marriage Amendment: The People's Choice On The Last Frontier| journal= Alaska Law Review |volume = 16 |issue = 2| pages = 213–268| author=Clarkson, Kevin, Coolidge, David, & Duncan, William |year=1999 |publisher= Duke University School of Law|accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref> Other U.S. states followed suit and passed similar amendments in the following years, reaching a peak of 31 in 2012. For more information, refer to [[U.S. state constitutional amendments banning same-sex unions]].
===1999=== * 12 January: [[Same-sex marriage in Belgium|Belgium]] approves a registered partnerships bill.<ref name="BelReg">{{cite web|url=https://same-sex.web.ined.fr/pdf/DocTrav125/05Doc125Belgium.pdf |title=Major legal consequences of marriage, cohabitation and registered partnership for different-sex and same-sex partners in Belgium |format=PDF |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> It became law on 1 January 2000.<ref name="BelReg"/> * March: [[LGBT rights in Spain|Spanish]] region of [[Aragon]] legalizes civil unions.<ref>{{es icon}} [[El Pais]]. ''[http://elpais.com/diario/1999/03/13/sociedad/921279613_850215.html Aragón aprueba su ley de parejas de hecho, la segunda de España].'' Retrieved 3 July 2015.</ref><ref>{{es icon}} [[El Pais]]. ''[http://elpais.com/diario/1999/11/03/sociedad/941583601_850215.html El Gobierno de Aragón regula el registro de las parejas de hecho].'' Retrieved 3 July 2015.</ref> * 22 September: Governor [[Gray Davis]] from the U.S. state of California signs a domestic partnerships bill into law that provided limited rights for same-sex couples.<ref>[http://www.leginfo.ca.gov/cgi-bin/postquery?bill_number=ab_26&sess=9900&house=B&author=migden AB 26.] Legislative Counsel of California. 1999–2000 Session.</ref> * 15 November: The [[French Parliament|Parliament]] of [[Same-sex marriage in France|France]] approves legislation (art. 515-1 et s. Code civil) that: :# creates a relationship register for both gay and straight couples (called "[[Pacte civil de solidarité]]" abbreviated as "PaCS"); and :# redefines the non-registered partnership as the stable union between two adults regardless of their gender (before this law, previous decisions of the French highest Court ruled that there could be no couple without appearance of marriage, therefore excluding gay people from any vision of family). * 20 December: The [[Supreme Court of Vermont|Supreme Court]] of the U.S. state of [[Same-sex marriage in Vermont|Vermont]] holds in ''[[Baker v. Vermont]]'' that excluding same-sex couples from marriage violates the [[Constitution of Vermont|Vermont Constitution]] and orders the legislature to establish same-sex marriage or an equivalent status.<ref>{{cite news|last=Goldberg|first=Carey|title=Vermont High Court Backs Rights of Same-Sex Couples|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/12/21/us/vermont-high-court-backs-rights-of-same-sex-couples.html|accessdate=22 September 2012|newspaper=New York Times|date=21 December 1999}}</ref>
==2000s==
===2000=== * 26 April: Governor [[Howard Dean]] from the U.S. state of [[Same-sex marriage in Vermont|Vermont]] signs a civil unions bill into law after the state's [[Supreme Court of Vermont|Supreme Court]] ruled that same-sex couples were entitled to the same rights as opposite sex couples, thus making Vermont the first state in the U.S. to give full marriage rights to same-sex couples.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.religioustolerance.org/hom_mar8d.htm |title=House Committee activity |publisher=Religioustolerance.org |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> It became law on 1 July. * 23 June: [[LGBT rights in Spain|Spanish]] region of [[Navarra]] legalizes same-sex civil unions. It also legalized joint adoption for same-sex couples, a first for the country.<ref>{{es icon}} [[El Pais]]. ''[http://elpais.com/diario/2000/09/15/paisvasco/969046827_850215.html El arzobispo de Pamplona arremete contra la ley navarra de parejas de hecho].'' Retrieved 3 July 2015.</ref><ref>{{es icon}} [[El Pais]]. ''[http://elpais.com/diario/2000/06/23/sociedad/961711215_850215.html Navarra permite por primera vez en España adoptar niños a las parejas homosexuales].'' Retrieved 3 July 2015.</ref> * November: [[Same-sex marriage in Germany|Germany]] approves a bill to legalize "Life partnerships". It became law on 1 August 2001. * '''21 December: [[Beatrix of the Netherlands|Queen Beatrix]] of the [[Netherlands]] signs into law the first same-sex marriage bill in the world.''' It had previously cleared the country's Senate on 19 December in a 49–26 vote<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/12/20/world/same-sex-dutch-couples-gain-marriage-and-adoption-rights.html |title=Same-Sex Dutch Couples Gain Marriage and Adoption Rights |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=20 December 2000 |accessdate=26 December 2011}}</ref> and the House of Representatives on 12 September in a 109–33 vote.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/09/13/world/dutch-legislators-approve-full-marriage-rights-for-gays.html?scp=2&sq=Norway+Gay+Marriages&st=nyt |title=Dutch Legislators Approve Full Marriage Rights for Gays |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=13 September 2000 |accessdate=26 December 2011}}</ref> The law came into effect on 1 April 2001.
===2001=== [[Image:Weddinginholland.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Two men marrying in [[Amsterdam]], in the first month after the [[Netherlands]] became the first country in the world to legalize same-sex marriage (2001).]] * 14 January: Two same-sex marriages are performed at the [[Metropolitan Community Church of Toronto]] in [[Ontario]], [[Same-sex marriage in Canada|Canada]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.samesexmarriage.ca/images/marriage_ceremony/Record-of-Marriage.gif |title=Record of Marriage |date=14 January 2001 |format=[[GIF]] }} signed by Rev. Brent Hawkes</ref> Although registration of the marriages was initially denied, a successful court challenge upheld their legality on 10 June 2003, thus retroactively making them '''the first legal same-sex marriages in modern times'''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.samesexmarriage.ca/legal/ontario_case/cer300604.htm |title=The first legal gay marriage is now certified }} Certificate of marriage, issued 11 June 2003.</ref> * '''1 April: Laws that permit marriage for same-sex couples and grant same-sex couples adoption rights in the [[Same-sex marriage in the Netherlands|Netherlands]] come into effect.''' Four same-sex couples are married at the stroke of midnight by the Mayor of [[Amsterdam]]. * 28 September: The Parliament of [[Finland]] approves a Registered Partnerships bill in a 99–84 vote.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Parliament narrowly passes law allowing same-sex registration |url=http://www2.hs.fi/english/archive/news.asp?id=20010928IE9 |publisher=Helsingin Sanomat |date=28 September 2001 |accessdate=13 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160112010242/http://www2.hs.fi/english/archive/news.asp?id=20010928IE9 |archivedate=12 January 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The law came into effect on 1 March 2002. * 11 December: [[LGBT rights in Spain|Spanish]] region of the [[Balearic Islands]] legalizes same-sex civil unions.<ref>{{es icon}} [[El Pais]]. ''[http://elpais.com/diario/2001/12/12/sociedad/1008111604_850215.html Ley de parejas de hecho en Baleares].'' Retrieved 3 July 2015.</ref> * 13 December: The [[Community of Madrid]], location of the capital of [[LGBT rights in Spain|Spain]], legalizes same-sex civil unions.<ref>{{es icon}} [[El Pais]]. ''[http://elpais.com/diario/2001/12/14/madrid/1008332662_850215.html La Asamblea aprueba la Ley de Parejas de Hecho con la abstención de PSOE e IU].'' Retrieved 3 July 2015.</ref>
=== 2002 === *June: the [[National Assembly of Quebec]] passed the ''Act Instituting Civil Unions and Establishing New Rules of Filiation''. This created civil unions, which allow both same-sex and opposite-sex couples to make a public commitment to live together and comply with the resulting rights and obligations.<ref>[http://www.justice.gouv.qc.ca/english/publications/generale/union-civ-a.htm Civil Unions] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150627081218/http://www.justice.gouv.qc.ca/english/publications/generale/union-civ-a.htm |date=27 June 2015 }}</ref> * 27 November: [[LGBT rights in Spain|Spanish]] region of [[Andalucia]] legalizes same-sex civil unions.<ref>{{es icon}} [[El Pais]]. ''[http://elpais.com/diario/2002/11/28/andalucia/1038439325_850215.html El Parlamento aprueba la ley de parejas de hecho con la oposición del PP al acogimiento de menores].'' Retrieved 3 July 2015.</ref>
===2003=== * '''13 February: King [[Albert II of Belgium|Albert II]] of Belgium signs a bill legalizing [[same-sex marriage in Belgium|same-sex marriage]] into law, making Belgium the second country in the world to legalize civil marriage for same-sex couples''', after the [[Same-sex marriage in the Netherlands|Netherlands]]. The bill previously passed the [[Chamber of Representatives (Belgium)|Chamber of Representatives]] in a 91–22 vote on 30 January 2003 and the [[Senate (Belgium)|Senate]] in a 46–15 vote on 13 December 2002. It came into effect on 1 June. * 1 May: The [[British Columbia Court of Appeal]] becomes the first provincial court of appeal to rule that the [[Canada|Canadian government]] must legally recognize same-sex marriage. * '''10 June: A court of appeals in [[Same-sex marriage in Canada|Canada]] legalizes same-sex marriage in the province [[Ontario]]''', ruling that restricting marriage to heterosexual couples contravened the equality provisions in the [[Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/story/2003/06/10/ont_samesex030610.html |title=Ontario men wed following court ruling |publisher=CBC News |date=13 June 2003 }}</ref> This makes Ontario the first jurisdiction in [[Americas|the Americas]] to legalize same-sex marriages. * 17 September: A registered partnership bill receives Royal Assent in [[Domestic partnership in Tasmania|Tasmania, Australia]]. It was previously approved by the state Legislative Council on 27 August and by the state House of Assembly on 25 June.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thelaw.tas.gov.au/tocview/index.w3p;cond=;doc_id=44%2B%2B2003%2BAT%40EN%2BSESSIONAL;histon=;prompt=;rec=;term= |title=Relationships Act 2003 |publisher=Thelaw.tas.gov.au |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> It came into effect on 1 January 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.justice.tas.gov.au/bdm/relationships |title=Tasmania: Births, Deaths, Marriage: Relationships |publisher=Justice.tas.gov.au |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> * 18 November: The [[Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court|Supreme Judicial Court]] of the U.S. state of [[Same-sex marriage in Massachusetts|Massachusetts]] rules in ''[[Goodridge v. Department of Public Health]]'' that orders that same-sex couples be allowed to marry beginning May 17, 2004, allowing the legislature six months to modify state law if it chooses to.<ref>{{cite news|last=Belluck| first=Pam| title=Marriage by Gays Gains Big Victory in Massachusetts|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/11/19/us/same-sex-marriage-overview-marriage-gays-gains-big-victory-massachusetts.html|accessdate=July 12, 2017|newspaper=New York Times|date=November 19, 2003}}</ref>
===2004=== * 12 January: The Legislature of the U.S. state of [[Same-sex marriage in New Jersey|New Jersey]] passes a registered partnerships bill. It came into effect on 10 July. * February/March: A number of jurisdictions in the U.S. begin issuing marriage licenses to same-sex couples, including [[San Francisco 2004 same-sex weddings|San Francisco, California]] (12 February), [[Sandoval County, New Mexico]] (20 February), [[New Paltz, New York]] (27 February), [[Multnomah County, Oregon]] (3 March) and [[Asbury Park, New Jersey]] (9 March). The licenses were later nullified (not necessarily in [[Sandoval County, New Mexico]]). * April: The U.S. state of [[Same-sex marriage in Maine|Maine]] adopts a registered partnerships bill. The law came into effect on 30 July.<ref>Me. Rev. Stat. Ann. tit. 22, sec. 2710</ref> * 12 May: The Parliament of [[Recognition of same-sex unions in Luxembourg|Luxembourg]] approves a civil partnerships bill.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gouvernement.lu/salle_presse/actualite/2004/05/12partenariat/index.html |title=La loi relative aux effets légaux de certains partenariats adoptée par la Chambre des députés |publisher=Gouvernement.lu |date=13 May 2004 |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.angloinfo.com/luxembourg/how-to/page/luxembourg-family-marriage-partnerships-the-partenariat-pacs-|title=The Partenariat (PACS) in Luxembourg|publisher=[[Angloinfo]]|accessdate=16 June 2016}}</ref> It came into effect on 1 November. * '''17 May: Same-sex marriage becomes legal in the U.S. state of [[Same-sex marriage in Massachusetts|Massachusetts]] after the Legislature failed to take any action in the 180 days period given by the state's Supreme Court.''' It became the first U.S. state to legalize same-sex marriage.<ref name="legal">{{cite news|first=Kathleen|last=Burge|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2003/11/18/sjc_gay_marriage_legal_in_mass/|title=SJC: Gay marriage legal in Mass.|publisher=The Boston Globe|date=18 November 2003}}</ref> * 5 November: A judge in [[Saskatchewan]], [[Same-sex marriage in Canada|Canada]], rules that same-sex couples must enjoy the right to equal marriage in that province. * 17 November: [[Recognition of same-sex unions in the United Kingdom|The United Kingdom]]'s parliament legalizes civil partnerships for same-sex couples. The bill received [[Royal Assent]] the next day and it took effect on 5 December 2005. * 30 November: The [[Supreme Court of Appeal of South Africa|Supreme Court of Appeal]] of [[Same-sex marriage in South Africa|South Africa]] rules that the common law concept of marriage must be extended to include same-sex couples. * 8 December: The government of [[Israel]] indicates that it will recognize same-sex partnerships for certain benefits. * 8 December: The Parliament of [[New Zealand]] approves a civil unions law by a vote of 65 to 55. The bill came into effect on 26 April 2005.
===2005=== * 23 March: The Principality of [[Recognition of same-sex unions in Andorra|Andorra]] legalizes same-sex unions.<ref>{{ca icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20100712203940/http://www.ilga-europe.org/content/download/10988/65125/file/Andorra%20registered%20cohabitation.pdf Llei 4/2005, del 21 de febrer, qualificada de les unions estables de parella]</ref> * 20 April: Governor [[Jodi Rell]] from the U.S. State of [[Same-sex marriage in Connecticut|Connecticut]] signs a same-sex civil unions bill into law after passing the State Senate 26 to 8 earlier that day. The bill was previously approved on 13 April by the State House of Representatives in an 85–63 vote. It came into effect on 1 October. * 5 June: A registered partnership law is approved in [[Switzerland]] by 58 percent of voters after opponents organized a ballot measure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/index/Fight_goes_on_for_gay_couples.html?cid=3943720 |title=Fight goes on for gay couples |publisher=Swissinfo.ch |date=10 June 2004 |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> It came into effect on 1 January 2007. * 22 June: A registered partnerships bill is approved in [[Recognition of same-sex unions in Slovenia|Slovenia]] giving same-sex couples limited rights.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.b92.net/eng/news/globe-article.php?yyyy=2006&mm=07&dd=25&nav_category=123&nav_id=35807 |title=Slovenia passes same-sex marriage law |publisher=B92.net |accessdate=26 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121023181358/http://www.b92.net/eng/news/globe-article.php?yyyy=2006&mm=07&dd=25&nav_category=123&nav_id=35807 |archivedate=23 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> It came into effect on 23 July 2006. * 23 June: A judge in [[New Brunswick]], Canada, rules that same-sex couples have the right to equal marriage in that province. * '''30 June: The Congress of Deputies of [[Same-sex marriage in Spain|Spain]] passes a same-sex marriage bill for a second time, overruling the rejection of the Spanish Senate a week before. This makes Spain the third country in the world to legalize same-sex marriage.''' The law took effect on 3 July, after it was publicized in the official government registry. King [[Juan Carlos I of Spain|Juan Carlos I]] granted the law [[Royal Assent]] the day after passage. * '''19 July: The Parliament of [[Same-sex marriage in Canada|Canada]] legalizes same-sex marriage, making Canada the first country in the Americas to legalize same-sex marriage and the fourth in the world to do so.''' It became law on 20 July after receiving Royal Assent. Eight of ten provinces and one of three territories in Canada already allowed same-sex marriage before being recognized federally. * 1 December: In the case of ''[[Minister of Home Affairs v Fourie]]'', the [[Constitutional Court of South Africa]] unanimously finds the restriction of marriage to opposite-sex couples to be unconstitutional, giving the country's Parliament one year to introduce same-sex marriage.
===2006=== * 15 March: The [[Czech Republic]]'s parliament passes a [[Registered partnership in the Czech Republic|registered partnership law]] with 101 votes (out of 177) overriding President [[Václav Klaus]], who previously vetoed the law on 16 February<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4811030.stm |title=Czech MPs approve gay rights law |publisher=BBC News |date=15 March 2006 |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> after it was approved by the lower and upper house in 2005. The law came into effect on 1 July.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.praguepost.com/archivescontent/1910-nearly-weds.html |title=Nearly weds |work=The Prague Post |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> * 18 May: King [[Albert II of Belgium]] signs a bill allowing adoption by same-sex couples into law after it was approved by the country's Senate on 20 April in a 34–33 vote. * 25 October: The [[New Jersey Supreme Court|Supreme Court]] of the U.S. state of [[Same-sex marriage in New Jersey|New Jersey]] unanimously rules in favor of same-sex marriage; 4–3 give the legislature six months to legalize same-sex marriage or civil unions. The three dissenting justices dissented because they believed same-sex couples should have the full right to marry.<ref>[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2006/10/26/MNGO5M02DV1.DTL Mixed decision for gay couples in New Jersey], ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]''</ref> * 9 November: The Legislative Assembly of [[Mexico City]] passes a civil union law, making it the first jurisdiction in Latin America to legally recognize same-sex unions. * 21 November: [[Israel]]'s supreme court rules that same-sex marriages performed abroad will be formally registered by the Israeli Interior Ministry. This ruling makes equal the status of same-sex couples and other Israeli couples who cannot be married by the formal religious institutions in Israel (e.g. couples from different religions). * '''29 November: Deputy President [[Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka]] of [[Same-sex marriage in South Africa|South Africa]] signs the [[Civil Union Act (South Africa)|Civil Union Act]] into law, making South Africa the first African country to legalise same-sex marriage.'''<ref>[http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/same-sex-marriages-now-legal-in-sa-1.305598 Same-sex marriages now legal in SA], iol.co.za, 30 November 2006.</ref> The bill was passed by the [[National Assembly of South Africa|National Assembly]] in a 229–41 vote on 14 November, and 36–11 by the [[National Council of Provinces]] on 28 November. The first wedding took place on 1 December. * 7 December: The Parliament of [[Same-sex marriage in Canada|Canada]] rejects Prime Minister [[Stephen Harper]]'s motion to re-open the equal marriage debate. The motion was defeated 175–123, and every political party had more MPs supporting same-sex marriage than in the previous vote. The prime minister declared the issue "settled". * 21 December: Governor [[Jon Corzine]] from the U.S. state of [[Same-sex marriage in New Jersey|New Jersey]] signs a bill legalizing civil unions into law.<ref name='njpl122106'>{{cite web|url=http://www.njleg.state.nj.us/2006/Bills/A4000/3787_I1.PDF |format=PDF|title=New Jersey Public Law 2006, c.103 |accessdate=31 July 2007 |year=2006 |publisher=New Jersey Legislature }}</ref> It took effect on 19 February 2007.
===2007=== * 12 January: The Mexican state of [[Coahuila]] legalizes civil unions, being the first state to do so in Mexico and the second entity (after [[Mexico City|Mexico D.F.]]). * 21 April: Governor [[Chris Gregoire]] from the U.S. state of [[Domestic partnership in Washington|Washington]] signs a domestic partnerships bill into law.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.governor.wa.gov/news/news-view.asp?pressRelease=551&newsType=1 |title = Governor Gregoire Signs Legislation Giving Legal Rights to Domestic Partners |publisher = Office of the Governor |accessdate = 19 March 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100325070613/http://www.governor.wa.gov/news/news-view.asp?pressRelease=551&newsType=1 |archivedate = 25 March 2010 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> It came into effect on 22 July. * 9 May: Governor [[Ted Kulongoski]] from the U.S. state of [[Domestic partnership in Oregon|Oregon]] signs a domestic partnerships bill into law. It came into effect on 1 February 2008. * 31 May: Governor [[John Lynch (New Hampshire)|John Lynch]] from the U.S. state of [[Same-sex marriage in New Hampshire|New Hampshire]] signs a civil unions bill into law. It came into effect on 1 January 2008. * 30 August: A court of the U.S. state of [[Same-sex marriage in Iowa|Iowa]] strikes down its ban on same-sex marriage as a result of a legal challenge. About 20 couples obtained marriage licenses and one couple married before the judge issued a stay of his ruling pending appeal.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/chi-gaymarriage_websep01,1,4408589.story |title=First Iowa gay marriage shows 'love and justice' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080907204548/http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/chi-gaymarriage_websep01,1,4408589.story |archivedate=7 September 2008 | work=Chicago Tribune}}, Rick Pearson, ''Chicago Tribune'', 31 August 2007</ref> * 27 December: President [[Tabaré Vázquez]] of [[Same-sex marriage in Uruguay|Uruguay]] signs a civil unions bill into law, becoming the first country in Latin America to approve a law giving legal recognition to same-sex couples.<ref>Writer, Staff. (28 December 2007) [http://www.pinknews.co.uk/news/articles/2005-6419.html Uruguay's President grants legal rights for gay couples]. Pinknews.co.uk. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> The bill was previously approved by the country's legislature on 19 December.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7151669.stm Uruguay approves gay civil unions]. BBC News (19 December 2007). Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> It came into effect on 1 January 2008.<ref>[http://larry50.wordpress.com/2008/01/04/uruguay-approves-gay-civil-unions/ Uruguay approves gay civil unions]. Larry50.wordpress.com (4 January 2008). Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref>
===2008=== * 15 April: A bill legalizing registered relationships receives Royal Assent in [[Victoria, Australia]]. It was previously approved by the State Legislative Council on 10 April and by the State Legislative Assembly on 12 March. The law came into effect on 1 December.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.samesame.com.au/news/local/3286/Victorian-Relationship-Register-Opens-Today.htm |title=Victorian Relationship Register Opens Today |publisher=Samesame.com.au |date=1 December 2008 |accessdate=26 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130525104444/http://www.samesame.com.au/news/local/3286/Victorian-Relationship-Register-Opens-Today.htm |archivedate=25 May 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> * 8 May: The Legislative Assembly of the [[Recognition of same-sex unions in the Australian Capital Territory|ACT]], Australia, passes a bill legalizing civil partnerships for same-sex couples.<ref>{{cite news |title=Watered down same-sex laws pass in ACT |publisher=Sydney Morning Herald |url=http://news.smh.com.au/watered-down-samesex-laws-pass-in-act/20080509-2ch7.html |accessdate=9 May 2008 |date=9 May 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511160041/http://news.smh.com.au/watered-down-samesex-laws-pass-in-act/20080509-2ch7.html |archivedate=11 May 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> It came into effect on 19 May. [[Image:Lyonandmartinwedding1.JPG|thumb|248px|right|First same-sex wedding in [[San Francisco]], [[Same-sex marriage in California|California]].]] * '''15 May: The [[Supreme Court of California|Supreme Court]] of the U.S. state of [[Same-sex marriage in California|California]] legalizes same-sex marriage''' in the landmark ''[[In re Marriage Cases]]'' ruling. The ruling took effect on 16 June. * 22 May: Governor [[Martin O'Malley]] of the U.S. state of [[Recognition of same-sex unions in Maryland|Maryland]] signs into law two bills legalizing domestic partnerships. They came into effect on 1 July. * 29 May: Governor [[David Paterson]] from the U.S. state of [[Same-sex marriage in New York|New York]] signs an executive order mandating state agencies to recognize same-sex marriages performed out-of-state equally under the law. New York thus became the first U.S. state that did not allow same-sex marriages{{citation needed|date=November 2014}}, but whose state agencies recognized same-sex marriages performed elsewhere. * ''' 17 June: [[Same-sex marriage in Norway|Norway]]'s upper house legalizes same-sex marriage in a 23–17 vote.''' The bill was previously approved by the lower house on 11 June in an 84–41 vote.<ref>{{cite news|author=From the Associated Press 1|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-on-norwaymarriage18-2008jun18,0,402614.story |title=Norway passes law approving gay marriage |work=Los Angeles Times |date=17 June 2008 |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> It came into effect on 1 January 2009. * 28 September: [[Recognition of same-sex unions in Ecuador|Ecuador]]'s new Constitution is approved by 63.9% of voters, legalizing [[Recognition of same-sex unions in Ecuador|civil unions for same-sex couples]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.towleroad.com/2008/09/ecuador-approve.html |title=Ecuador Approves New Constitution Including Same-Sex Civil Unions |publisher=Towleroad.com |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7637458.stm Ecuador's poor bank on referendum]. Bbc.co.uk (27 September 2008). Retrieved on 8 February 2012.</ref> The country's first same-sex civil union was performed on 12 August 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vistazo.com/ea/pais/?eImpresa=1009&id=2781|title=Uniones gays ya son legales|publisher=Vistazo.com|accessdate=10 February 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120419115841/http://www.vistazo.com/ea/pais/?eImpresa=1009&id=2781|archivedate=19 April 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * '''10 October: The [[Supreme Court of Connecticut|Supreme Court]] of the U.S. state of [[Same-sex marriage in Connecticut|Connecticut]] legalizes same-sex marriage''' in the landmark ''Kerrigan and Mock v. Connecticut Department of Public Health'' ruling.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Michael Levenson |author2=Andrew Ryan |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Connecticut Supreme Court legalizes same-sex marriage|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/breaking_news/2008/10/connecticut_sup.html|work=The Boston Globe|date=10 October 2008|accessdate=26 November 2010}}</ref> Same-sex weddings started on 12 November. * 4 November: A referendum seeking to constitutionally ban same-sex marriages in the U.S. state of [[California Proposition 8 (2008)|California]] is approved by 52.2% of voters;<ref name='statementofvote'>{{cite web|url=http://www.sos.ca.gov/elections/sov/2008_general/sov_complete.pdf |title=Statement of Vote: 2008 General Election |format=PDF |publisher=[[California Secretary of State]] |date=13 December 2008 |accessdate=10 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018225250/http://www.sos.ca.gov/elections/sov/2008_general/sov_complete.pdf |archivedate=18 October 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> thus '''overturning same-sex marriage in California''', this event being noteworthy because it was the first time in modern history that same-sex marriage has been overturned. * 19 November: The [[Supreme Court of Nepal|Supreme Court]] of [[Same-sex marriage in Nepal|Nepal]] orders the government to legalize same-sex marriage.
===2009=== * 28 January: The [[Constitutional Court of Colombia|Constitutional Court]] of [[Recognition of same-sex unions in Colombia|Colombia]] rules that same-sex couples are entitled to the same rights as heterosexual couples in [[common-law marriage]]s. The ruling means that civil and political rights such as nationality, residency, housing protection, and state benefits are now granted to same-sex partners.<ref>{{cite web | author=Partners Task Force for Gay & Lesbian Couples | title=Common Law Marriage: The Colombian Approach | date=29 January 2009 | url=http://www.buddybuddy.com/d-p-colo.html | accessdate=11 January 2010}}</ref> * '''1 April: The Parliament of [[Same-sex marriage in Sweden|Sweden]] legalizes same-sex marriage in a 226–22 vote.'''<ref>{{cite news| title=Sweden allows same-sex marriage| date=2 April 2009 | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/7978495.stm | accessdate=20 February 2012|work=BBC News}}</ref> The law came into effect on 1 May. * '''3 April: The [[Supreme Court of Iowa|Supreme Court]] of the U.S. state of [[Same-sex marriage in Iowa|Iowa]] unanimously votes to legalize same-sex marriage''' in the landmark ''[[Varnum v. Brien]]'' ruling.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.365gay.com/news/iowa-supreme-court-strikes-down-gay-marriage-ban/ |title=Iowa Supreme Court strikes down gay marriage ban |publisher=365gay.com |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> Same-sex weddings started on 27 April. * '''7 April: The U.S. state of [[Same-sex marriage in Vermont|Vermont]] legalizes same-sex marriage after a 23–5 vote in the State Senate and a 100–49 vote in the House of Representatives''', overriding Governor [[Jim Douglas]], who had vetoed the law a day earlier.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/04/07/vermont-legalizes-gay-mar_n_184034.html|title= Vermont Legalizes Gay Marriage, Overrides Governor's Veto |last=Gram|first=Dave|date=7 April 2009|work=Huffington Post|accessdate=25 January 2012}}</ref> The bill came into effect on 1 September. * 20 April: The Parliament of [[Recognition of same-sex unions in Hungary|Hungary]] legalizes registered partnerships in a 199–159 vote.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ilga-europe.org/home/guide/country_by_country/hungary/hungary_introduces_registered_partnership_for_same_sex_partners|title=Hungary introduces registered partnership for same-sex partners|accessdate=14 October 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121102114639/http://ilga-europe.org/home/guide/country_by_country/hungary/hungary_introduces_registered_partnership_for_same_sex_partners|archivedate=2 November 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The law came into effect on 1 July. * 6 May: Governor [[John Baldacci]] from the U.S. state of [[Same-sex marriage in Maine|Maine]] signs a same-sex marriage bill into law.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maine.gov/tools/whatsnew/index.php?topic=Gov+News&id=72146&v=Article-2006 |title=Governor Signs LD 1020, An Act to End Discrimination in Civil Marriage and Affirm Religious Freedom |publisher=Maine.gov |date=6 May 2009 |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> The bill was previously approved 89-58 by the House of Representatives a day earlier and 21-14 by the State Senate on 30 April. However, opponents organized a referendum that took place on 3 November. * 18 May: Governor [[Chris Gregoire]] from the U.S. state of [[Same-sex marriage in Washington|Washington]] signs the so-called "everything-but-marriage" registered partnerships bill into law.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.governor.wa.gov/news/news-view.asp?pressRelease=1236&newsType=1 |title=Gov. Gregoire signs legislation to expand rights to domestic partners |publisher=Governor.wa.gov |date=18 May 2009 |accessdate=26 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120215064133/http://www.governor.wa.gov/news/news-view.asp?pressRelease=1236&newsType=1 |archivedate=15 February 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps.leg.wa.gov/billinfo/summary.aspx?bill=5688&year=2009 |title=SB 5688 – 2009–10 |publisher=Apps.leg.wa.gov |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> It was passed by the State Senate on 10 March and by the House of Representatives on 15 April. However, opponents organized a referendum that took place on 3 November. * 26 May: [[California Supreme Court]] upholds [[California Proposition 8 (2008)|Proposition 8]], constitutionally banning same-sex marriage, but rules that previously officiated same-sex marriages shall remain valid. * 31 May: The Assembly of the U.S. state of [[Recognition of same-sex unions in Nevada|Nevada]] legalizes domestic partnerships by a 28–14 vote,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2009/may/30/senate-overrides-governors-veto-domestic-partners-/|title=Senate overrides governor's veto of domestic partners bill|author=Cy Ryan|work=LasVegasSun.com|accessdate=14 October 2014}}</ref> overriding a veto from Governor [[Jim Gibbons (U.S. politician)|Jim Gibbons]] after the Senate did the same on 30 May by a 14–7 vote.<ref name=House>{{cite web|url=http://www.ktnv.com/Global/story.asp?S=10453082|title=House overrides governor's veto of domestic partners bill|work=KTNV|accessdate=14 October 2014}}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The law came into effect on 1 October.<ref name=House/> * '''3 June: Governor [[John Lynch (New Hampshire)|John Lynch]] from the U.S. State of [[Same-sex marriage in New Hampshire|New Hampshire]] signs a bill legalizing same-sex marriage into law''' after being approved 14–10 by the State Senate and 198–176 by the House of Representatives.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/domesticNews/idUSTRE5526NV20090603 | title=New Hampshire legalizes gay marriage | date=3 June 2009 | work=Reuters}}</ref> The law took effect on 1 January 2010. * 29 June: Governor [[Jim Doyle]] from the U.S. state of [[Recognition of same-sex unions in Wisconsin|Wisconsin]] signs into law a bill legalizing registered partnerships. The bill was previously approved by the State Assembly in a 50–48 vote on 13 June<ref name=fairwisconsin>State Assembly Votes to Approve Domestic Partnerships!, Fair Wisconsin</ref> and by the State Senate in a 17–16 vote on 17 June.<ref name=fairwisconsin /> The law came into effect on 3 August. * 1 July: The U.S. state of [[Recognition of same-sex unions in Colorado|Colorado]] begins recognizing designated beneficiary agreements.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_12109357 |title=Ritter signs bill that will help gay couples – The Denver Post|work=Denver Post |accessdate=29 April 2009|date=9 April 2009}}</ref> * 6 July: The [[Same-sex marriage in the District of Columbia|District of Columbia]] starts recognizing same-sex marriages performed in other U.S. states, although same-sex marriages cannot be performed in D.C. itself. * 3 November: A referendum in the U.S. state of [[Same-sex marriage in Maine|Maine]] repeals an approved same-sex marriage bill before it took effect,<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/11/04/maine.same.sex/index.html | work=CNN | title=Maine rejects same-sex marriage law | date=5 November 2009}}</ref> while a referendum in the US state of [[Same-sex marriage in Washington|Washington]] upholds the so-called "everything-but-marriage" registered partnerships bill,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://vote.wa.gov/results/current/Referendum-Measure-No-74-Concerns-marriage-for-same-sex-couples_ByCounty.html |title=Referendum Measure No. 74 Concerns marriage for same-sex couples |publisher=Vote.wa.gov |accessdate=12 December 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121110052959/http://vote.wa.gov/results/current/Referendum-Measure-No-74-Concerns-marriage-for-same-sex-couples_ByCounty.html |archive-date=10 November 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> which came into effect on 3 December. * '''18 December: [[Same-sex marriage in the District of Columbia|District of Columbia]] Mayor [[Adrian Fenty]] signs a same-sex marriage bill into law'''.<ref>{{cite web | author=The Christian Press | title=D.C. Mayor Signs Gay Marriage Bill | date=21 December 2009 | url=http://www.christianpost.com/article/20091221/d-c-mayor-signs-gay-marriage-bill/ | accessdate=22 December 2009}}</ref> The bill was previously approved by the D.C. Council on 15 December.<ref>{{cite news | author=The Washington Post | title=D.C. Council approves same-sex marriage bill | date=16 December 2009 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/12/15/AR2009121500945.html?hpid=moreheadlines | accessdate=22 December 2009}}</ref> It came into effect on 3 March 2010.<ref>{{cite news|last=Gresko |first=Jessica |title=Same-sex marriage becomes legal in DC |agency=Associated Press |publisher=[[Google News]] |date=3 March 2010 |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gftV6RnfBC8iPPWGM0SGQeNLiC6QD9E71J3G0 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nx4LhJxv?url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gftV6RnfBC8iPPWGM0SGQeNLiC6QD9E71J3G0 |archivedate=3 March 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> * 18 December: The Federal Council (upper house) of [[Recognition of same-sex unions in Austria|Austria]]'s passes a bill legalizing registered partnerships in a 44–8 vote.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ggg.at/index.php?id=62&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=2696&cHash=c6fe822c0758046b6f60c9830b3d80c7|title=Bundesrat beschließt Homo-Ehe|work=GGG.at|date=18 December 2009|language=de}}</ref> The bill was previously passed by the National Council (lower house) on 10 December in a 110–64 vote.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.365gay.com/news/austrian-parliament-oks-gay-civil-unions/|title=Austrian parliament OKs gay civil unions|work=365Gay|date=10 December 2009|agency=Associated Press|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091214181836/http://www.365gay.com/news/austrian-parliament-oks-gay-civil-unions/|archivedate=14 December 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref> It came into effect on 1 January 2010. * 28 December: The first same-sex marriage in [[Same-sex marriage in Argentina|Argentina]] and Latin America is conducted in [[Ushuaia]], province of [[Tierra del Fuego Province (Argentina)|Tierra del Fuego]]. The couple first planned to marry in Buenos Aires on 1 December after a city court ruled that it should be issued a marriage license;<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/lifestyleMolt/idUSTRE5AC32X20091113 | work=Reuters | title=Argentine judge allows gay wedding in legal first | date=13 November 2009}}</ref> however, a national judge blocked the marriage from taking place in Buenos Aires. The couple successfully married in Ushuaia thanks to Governor [[Fabiana Ríos]]'s intervention.<ref>{{cite news|agency=Associated Press |title=Gay marriage in Argentina is 1st in Latin America |date=28 December 2009 |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/lt_argentina_gay_marriage |accessdate=28 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091211190349/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/lt_argentina_gay_marriage |archivedate=11 December 2009 }}</ref> * '''29 December: [[Same-sex marriage in Mexico City|Mexico City]]'s Head of Government [[Marcelo Ebrard]] signs a same-sex marriage bill into law.'''<ref>{{cite news | author=Tracy Wilkinson |work=Los Angeles Times | title=Gay marriage closer to reality in Mexico | date=29 December 2009 | url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/laplaza/2009/12/gay-marriage-closer-to-reality-in-mexico.html | accessdate=30 December 2009}}</ref> The bill was previously approved on 21 December by the Legislative Assembly in a 39–20 vote. It took effect on 3 March 2010.<ref>{{cite news | author=Elisabeth Malkin |work=New York Times | title=Gay Marriage Puts Mexico City at Center of Debate | date=6 February 2010 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/07/world/americas/07mexico.html | accessdate=12 February 2010}}</ref> [[Recognition of same-sex unions in Mexico#Same-sex civil unions|Civil unions]] in Mexico City had been available since 2007, but full marriage was not yet recognized.<ref>{{cite news | agency=Associated Press | title=Mexico City 1st in region to approve gay marriage | date=21 December 2009 | url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5grJesfflOb0tjV_flyYRem81BVMwD9CNUCH00 | accessdate=21 December 2009}}</ref>
==2010s==
===2010=== * '''17 May: President of Portugal [[Aníbal Cavaco Silva]] signs a [[Same-sex marriage in Portugal|same-sex marriage bill]] into law''', making Portugal the sixth country in Europe, and eighth country overall, to legalize same-sex marriages.<ref>[http://www.towleroad.com/2010/05/portugals-president-to-sign-samesex-marriage-into-law.html Portugal's President to Sign Same-Sex Marriage into Law] ''towleroad.com'' Retrieved 1 March 2012.</ref> The country's Assembly previously approved the bill in its second reading on 11 February.<ref>{{cite web |author=a |url=http://m24digital.com/en/2010/02/12/gay-marriage-approved-by-the-portuguese-parliament/ |title=Gay marriage approved by the Portuguese Parliament |publisher=M24digital.com |date=25 January 2011 |accessdate=26 July 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120723131649/http://m24digital.com/en/2010/02/12/gay-marriage-approved-by-the-portuguese-parliament/ |archive-date=23 July 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> It took effect on 5 June.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dre.pt/pdf1sdip/2010/05/10500/0185301853.pdf |title=Lei n.º 9/2010 de 31 de Maio |format=PDF |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> * 19 May: A registered partnerships bill receives [[Royal Assent]] in [[New South Wales]], Australia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/parlment/nswbills.nsf/7bd7da67ee5a02c5ca256e67000c8755/57f8af30e6a0d630ca25770d001af7dc?OpenDocument |title=Relationships Register Bill 2010 |publisher=Parliament.nsw.gov.au |accessdate=26 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121022222722/http://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/parlment/nswbills.nsf/7bd7da67ee5a02c5ca256e67000c8755/57f8af30e6a0d630ca25770d001af7dc?OpenDocument |archivedate=22 October 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> The bill was previously approved by the state upper House on 12 May in a 32–5 vote and by the state lower House on 11 May in a 62–9 vote. The law came into effect on 1 July.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.samesame.com.au/news/local/5577/NSW-couples-can-register-from-today.htm |title=NSW couples can register from today |publisher=Samesame.com.au |accessdate=26 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314125223/http://www.samesame.com.au/news/local/5577/NSW-couples-can-register-from-today.htm |archivedate=14 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * '''11 June: The Parliament of [[Iceland]] unanimously approves a law legalizing [[Same-sex marriage in Iceland|same-sex marriage]] by a vote of 49–0.'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icenews.is/index.php/2010/06/28/new-gay-marriage-law-in-iceland-comes-into-force/ |title=New gay marriage law in Iceland comes into force |publisher=Icenews.is |date=28 June 2010 |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> The law took effect on 27 June. * 27 June: [[Jóhanna Sigurðardóttir]], [[Iceland]]'s Prime minister, becomes the world's first head of government to enter a same-sex marriage.<ref>[https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hSl5aRhJRk0Y00xcnrpK-4eWlz0gD9GLP4484 Icelandic leader in milestone gay marriage] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100704155648/https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hSl5aRhJRk0Y00xcnrpK-4eWlz0gD9GLP4484 |date=4 July 2010 }}</ref> * 19 July: President [[Mary McAleese]] of [[Same-sex marriage in Ireland|Ireland]] signs into law a bill legalizing Civil Partnerships. It was previously passed by the Seanad in a 48–4 vote on 8 July.<ref>{{cite web|author=8 July 2010 – 18:55:14 |url=http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/civil-partnership-bill-passes-all-stages-464761.html |title=Civil Partnership Bill passes all stages |publisher=Breakingnews.ie |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> The law came into effect on 1 January 2011.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2011/0101/breaking25.html |title=Partnership laws come into force |work=The Irish Times |date=1 January 2011 |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> [[File:Enactment of the Egalitarian marriage law.jpg|thumb|250px|President of [[Argentina]], [[Cristina Fernández]], signs the bill legalizing same-sex marriage.]] * '''21 July: President [[Cristina Fernández de Kirchner|Cristina Fernandez]] of [[Same-sex marriage in Argentina|Argentina]] signs a same-sex marriage bill into law,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2010/07/21/law-legalizing-sex-marriage-argentina-takes-effect-president-signs-ceremony/ |title=Law legalizing same-sex marriage in Argentina takes effect as president signs bill at ceremony |publisher=Fox News |accessdate=26 July 2012 |date=21 July 2010}}</ref> making Argentina the first country in both South America and Latin America, and the second country in the Americas, to legalize same-sex marriage nationwide'''. The bill was previously approved by the country's Senate 33-27 on 15 July<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10630683 |title=Argentine Senate backs bill legalising gay marriage |publisher=BBC |date=15 July 2010 |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> and 125–109 by the Chamber of Deputies on 5 May.<ref>{{cite web|author=Shayla Hoegerl |url=http://momento24.com/en/2010/05/05/lower-house-approves-gay-marriage/ |title=Lower House approves gay marriage |publisher=Momento24.com |date=14 October 2010 |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> The first marriage took place on 30 July.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-10823279 |title=Argentine gay couple tie knot under new marriage law |publisher=BBC |date=30 July 2010 |accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> * 4 August: [[U.S. District Court|U.S. District Court of Northern California]] declares that [[California Proposition 8 (2008)|Proposition 8]], a 2008 California-electorate ban on same-sex marriage, violates [[due process]] and [[equal protection]] clauses in the [[U.S. Constitution]].<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/2010/aug/04/local/la-mew-prop-8-10042010 Judge strikes down Prop. 8, allows gay marriage in California] ''LA Times'' Retrieved 1 March 2012.</ref> Supporters of the proposition eventually appealed all the way to the Supreme Court, which issued a ruling in 2013. * 5 August: The [[Supreme Court of Justice of the Nation|Supreme Court]] of [[Mexico]] votes 8–2 to uphold the constitutionality of Mexico City's same-sex marriage law.<ref>{{cite news|agency=Reuters|title=Mexico court upholds gay marriage law|date=5 August 2010|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/08/05/us-mexico-gaymarraige-idUSTRE6745RD20100805|accessdate=1 March 2012}}</ref> On the following days, it also votes to mandate that all 31 states of Mexico must recognize same-sex marriages performed in other jurisdictions (on 10 August, on a 9–2 vote)<ref>{{cite web|title=Mexican Supreme Court: Gay Marriage Be Recognized in all 31 States|url=http://www.zimbio.com/Same-sex+marriages/articles/2ys0o6TBNgB/Mexican+states+must+recognize+gay+marriages|publisher=zimbio.com|accessdate=11 February 2012}}</ref> and to uphold a Mexico City law permitting same-sex couples entering into marriages to adopt children (on 16 August, on a 9–2 vote).<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/americas/08/16/mexico.gay.adoption/index.html Mexican high court upholds adoptions by same-sex couples] ''CNN.com'' Retrieved 1 March 2012.</ref> * 10 August: The [[Supreme Court of Justice of Costa Rica|Supreme Court]] of [[Recognition of same-sex unions in Costa Rica|Costa Rica]] issues a 5–2 ruling to halt a referendum on same-sex civil unions which was scheduled for 5 December after stating that minority rights should not be decided by the majority.<ref>[http://www.voanews.com/english/news/americas/Costa-Rica-Court-Rejects-Vote-on-Same-Sex-Civil-Unions-100430779.html Costa Rica Court Rejects Vote on Same-Sex Civil Unions] ''Voice of America News''.
