===2018=== *9 January: After a motion presented by [[Costa Rica]] requesting clarifications on the rights of same-sex couples, the [[Inter-American Court of Human Rights]] ruled that all signatory parties of the [[Pact of San José]] were required to provide the same rights to same-sex couples, including marriage, possibly legalizing same-sex marriage in most of the Americas. The governments of Costa Rica and Panama announced that they would comply.<ref name="IACHR">{{cite web|url=https://au.news.yahoo.com/world/a/38550305/inter-american-court-endorses-same-sex-marriage/|title=Inter-American Court endorses same-sex marriage|work=[[Agence France-Presse]]|publisher=[[Yahoo7]]|date=9 January 2018|accessdate=9 January 2018|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180109235924/https://au.news.yahoo.com/world/a/38550305/inter-american-court-endorses-same-sex-marriage/|archivedate=9 January 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://laestrella.com.pa/panama/nacional/panama-acoge-opinion-corte-sobre-matrimonio/24043659 |title=Panamá acoge a la opinión de Corte IDH sobre matrimonio gay |publisher=[[La Estrella de Panamá]] |date=16 January 2018}}</ref> *1 June: '''Same-sex marriage is no longer legal in Bermuda.''' *5 June: The [[European Court of Justice]] rules that EU member states should recognise same-sex marriages for the purpose of residency if at least 1 person is an EU citizen. [[Slovakia]] announces that they will comply with this ruling, recognising marriages performed abroad.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20843250/same-sex-married-couples-have-the-right-to-stay-in-slovakia.html|title=Same-sex married couples have the right to stay in Slovakia|first=Petit Press |last=a.s.|publisher=}}</ref> *6 June: [[Supreme Court of Bermuda|Supreme Court]] of [[Bermuda]] strikes down the ban on same-sex marriage, five days after the ban goes into effect.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/same-sex-marriage/article/20180606/court-rules-in-favour-of-same-sex-marriage|title= Court rules in favour of same-sex marriage|publisher=Royal Gazette|accessdate= 6 June 2018}}</ref> *13 June: 46 deputies in the [[Czech Republic|Czech]] parliament introduce a bill which would legalise same-sex marriage in the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lidovky.cz/dustojnost-pro-vsechny-poslanci-navrhli-aby-manzelstvi-mohli-uzavirat-i-lide-stejneho-pohlavi-i2d-/zpravy-domov.aspx?c=A180613_161954_ln_domov_ele|title=‚Důstojnost pro všechny.‘ Poslanci navrhli, aby manželství mohli uzavírat i lidé stejného pohlaví - Domov - Lidovky.cz|website=Lidovky.cz}}</ref> *14 June: '''Same-sex marriage becomes legal in [[Same-sex marriage in Guernsey|Alderney]].'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alderney.gov.gg/CHttpHandler.ashx?id=113475&p=0|title=The Same-Sex Marriage (Alderney) Law, 2017 (Commencement) Ordinance, 2018|publisher=States of Alderney|accessdate=6 June 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180606090843/http://www.alderney.gov.gg/CHttpHandler.ashx?id=113475&p=0|archivedate=6 June 2018}}</ref> *19 June: The Supreme Court of the [[Philippines]] begins hearing a case to legalise same-sex marriage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/news/nation/657294/supreme-court-to-hear-arguments-on-same-sex-marriage-tuesday-june-19-2018/story/|title=Supreme Court to hear arguments on same-sex marriage Tuesday, June 19, 2018|publisher=}}</ref> *29 June: 2 family judges in [[Ecuador]] rule that same-sex couples have a right to marry.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.eltiempo.com.ec/noticias/cuenca/2/boda-lgbti-espera-sentencia|title=Boda LGBTI espera sentencia|first=EL|last=TIEMPO|date=4 July 2018|publisher=}}</ref> *1 July: '''Same-sex marriage becomes legal in [[Same-sex marriage in Jersey|Jersey]].'''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://statesassembly.gov.je/Pages/Propositions.aspx?infoid=A1B0C43F-4192-4BFE-9FC1-53AAEC8F5208|title=Propositions|first=States of|last=Jersey|website=statesassembly.gov.je}}</ref> *22 July: The National Assembly of [[Cuba]] approves new constitutional changes, setting a referendum on same-sex marriage on 24 February 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.efe.com/efe/english/world/cuba-s-national-assembly-concludes-debate-on-constitutional-reforms/50000262-3698805|title=Cuba's National Assembly concludes debate on constitutional reforms|publisher=}}</ref>{{Failed verification|date=October 2018}} *10 August: The Supreme Court of Costa Rica orders that same-sex marriage must be legalised by 2020.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-45138687|title=Costa Rica court: End gay marriage ban|date=10 August 2018|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref> *4 September: Senator [[Germán Martínez]] introduces a bill to legalise same-sex marriage federally in [[Mexico]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://acustiknoticias.com/2018/09/martinez-cazares-busca-reconocimiento-del-matromonio-igualitario-ante-imss-e-issste/|title=Martínez Cázares busca reconocimiento del matromonio igualitario ante IMSS e ISSSTE - Acustik Noticias|date=4 September 2018|publisher=}}</ref> *10 September: The Labor Chamber of the Provincial Court of Justice of Ecuador overturns earlier court decisions legalising same-sex marriage, ruling that legalisation is a decision for the National Assembly or the Constitutional Court.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.eltelegrafo.com.ec/noticias/judicial/12/corte-justicia-matrimonioigualitario-lgbti|title=Corte de Justicia rechaza matrimonio igualitario|first=El|last=Telégrafo|date=11 September 2018|publisher=}}</ref> *7 October: A [[Romanian constitutional referendum, 2018|referendum to constitutionally ban same-sex marriage]] in [[Romania]] fails due to low turnout.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://prezenta.bec.ro/|title=Prezenta vot|website=prezenta.bec.ro}}</ref> *16 November: [[Recognition of same-sex unions in San Marino|San Marino]] passes civil unions legislation in a vote of 40 to 4.<ref>https://www.gaystarnews.com/article/san-marino/#gs.mW==Tds</ref>

est. 2,000{{cite web |author=Zaman|title=Altepe'den Hırvat Müslümanlara moral|url=http://www.zaman.com.tr/haber.do?haberno=1165160&title=altepeden-hirvat-muslumanlara-moral|accessdate=2011-09-09}} |region1 = [[Primorje-Gorski Kotar County]] |pop1 = 67 |ref1 = |region2 = [[Zagreb|City of Zagreb]] |pop2 = 65 |ref2 = |region3 = [[Istria County]] |pop3 = 57 |ref3 = |region4 = [[Split-Dalmatia County]] |pop4 = 24 |ref4 = |region5 = [[Brod-Posavina County]] |pop5 = 19 |ref5 = |region6 = |pop6 = |ref6 = |region7 = |pop7 = |ref7 = |region8 = |pop8 = |ref8 = |region9 = |pop9 = |ref9 = |region10 = |pop10 = |ref10 = |languages = [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Croatian language|Croatian]] |religions = [[Sunni Islam]] |related = |footnotes = }} '''Turks of Croatia''' ({{lang-hr|Turci u Hrvatskoj}}; {{lang-tr|Hırvatistan Türkleri}}) are one among 22 recognised national minorities in [[Croatia]]. According to the 2011 census, there were 367 [[Turkish people|Turks]] living in [[Croatia]], most of which most lived in [[Primorje-Gorski Kotar County]]. Turks compose approximately 0.001% of the total population. The majority of Croatian Turks are [[Sunni Islam|Sunni Muslims]], and make up 0.5% of Croatia's Muslim population (56,777 Muslims in total). == Culture == In the [[Independent State of Croatia]], the Croatian Muslim Printing House issued a magazine in [[Turkish language]] intended for the Turkish public, the European turkologists and those in the Independent State of Croatia who spoke Turkish language. The magazine was called ''The East and the West: the Cultural, Economic, Social and Political Magazine'' ({{lang-tr|Doğu ve Batı. Kültür, iktisat, sosyal ve siyasi mecmuası}}). It was issued between 6 April 1943 and 15 August 1944. It was the first magazine in Turkish language on the territory of the present-day [[Croatia]] and [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]], and second on the territory of the former [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]].{{sfn|Vlašić|5 December 2013}} == Population == {| class="toccolours sortable" border="1" cellpadding="0" cellpadding="5" |+ |- bgcolor=#B0C4DE ! Official name of Croatia!! Year!! Number of Turks |- | - || 1931 || 186 |- |rowspan="3"| {{flag|SR Croatia|name=PR Croatia}} || 1948|| 13 |- | 1953 || 276 |- | 1961 || 2,710 |- |rowspan="2"| {{flag|SR Croatia}} || 1971 || 221 |- | 1981 || 279 |- |rowspan="3"| {{flag|Croatia}} || 1991 || 320 |- | 2001 || 300 |- | 2011 || 367 |- |colspan=3|(Croatian Bureau of Statistics)[http://www.vojska.net/eng/armed-forces/croatia/about/population/ Population of Croatia 1931-2001] |} ==Notable people== *[[Banu Alkan]], Turkish actress == See also == * [[Turkish minorities in the former Ottoman Empire]] ** [[Turks in the Balkans]] == References == === Notes === {{Reflist}} === Journals === {{refbegin}} * {{cite journal |last=Vlašić |first=Anđelko |date=5 December 2013 |title=Doğu ve Batı: hrvatski list na turskom jeziku (1943. – 1944.) |url=http://behar.hr/dogu-ve-bati-istok-i-zapad-hrvatski-list-na-turskom-jeziku-1943-1944/ |journal=Behar |publisher=Kulturno društvo Bošnjaka Hrvatske Preporod |volume= |issue=115 |pages= |doi= |access-date=12 June 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131210031129/http://behar.hr/dogu-ve-bati-istok-i-zapad-hrvatski-list-na-turskom-jeziku-1943-1944/ |archivedate=10 December 2013 |df= }} {{refend}} {{Ethnic groups in Croatia}} {{Turkish diaspora}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in Croatia]] [[Category:Muslim communities in Europe]] [[Category:Turkish diaspora by country|Croatia]] [[Category:Middle Eastern diaspora in Croatia]] [[Category:Turkish diaspora in Europe|Croatia]] [[Category:Croatian people of Turkish descent| ]]

{{infobox ethnic group| | group = Wodaabe ''Woɗaaɓe'' | image = [[File:1997 277-2A Wodaabe leaving camp.jpg|none|250px]] | image_caption = A group of traveling Wodaabe. Niger, 1997 | population = 45,000 (2010) | popplace = {{Flag|Niger}}, {{Flag|Cameroon}}, {{Flag|Central African Republic}}, {{Flag|Chad}}, {{Flag|Nigeria}} | rels = [[Islam]], [[African traditional religion]] | langs = [[Fula language|Fula]] | related = [[Fula people|Fula]] }} The '''Wodaabe''' ({{lang-ff|Woɗaaɓe}}), also known as the '''Mbororo''' or '''Bororo''', are a small subgroup of the [[Fula people|Fulani]] [[ethnic group]]. They are traditionally [[nomad]]ic cattle-herders and traders in the [[Sahel]], with migrations stretching from southern [[Niger]], through northern [[Nigeria]], northeastern [[Cameroon]], southwestern [[Chad]], and the western region of the [[Central African Republic]].<ref name="Uiowa">{{Cite web|url=https://africa.uima.uiowa.edu/peoples/show/Wodaabe|publisher="[[University of Iowa]] "|title=Wodaabe People}}</ref> The number of Wodaabe was estimated in 2001 to be 100,000.<ref>http://fernwhitehilsenrath.wordpress.com/tag/the-wodaabe-tribe/</ref><ref>https://books.google.ca/books?id=54gyRnhIugkC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false</ref> They are known for their elaborate attire and rich cultural ceremonies.
The Wodaabe speak the [[Fula language]] and don't use a written language.<ref name=ng>Carol Beckwith, [http://iws.collin.edu/mbailey/wodaabe.pdf Niger's Wodaabe: "People of the Taboo"]. ''National Geographic'', 1983, vol. 164, no4, pp. 483-509</ref> In the Fula language, ''woɗa'' means "[[taboo]]", and ''Woɗaaɓe'' means "people of the taboo". This is sometimes translated as "those who respect taboos", a reference to the Wodaabe isolation from broader Fulbe culture, and their contention that they retain "older" traditions than their Fulbe neighbors.<ref>Loftsdóttir, Kristín. When nomads lose cattle: Wodaabe negotiations of ethnicity. African Sociological Review 2004, 8(2): 52-76</ref> In contrast, other Fulbe as well as other ethnic groups sometimes refer to the Wodaabe as "'''Mbororo'''", a sometimes pejorative name,<ref name=beck1985>Carol Beckwith. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/3336256 An Interview with Carol Beckwith]. African Arts, Vol. 18, No. 4 (Aug., 1985), pp. 38-45</ref> translated into English as "Cattle Fulani", and meaning "those who dwell in cattle camps".<ref>EA BRACKENBURY. [http://afraf.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/pdf_extract/XXIII/XCI/208 NOTES ON THE "BORORO FULBE" OR NOMAD "CATTLE FULANI"] African Affairs, vol. XXIII, number 208, 1924</ref> By the 17th century, the Fula people across West Africa were among the first ethnic groups to embrace Islam, were often leaders of those forces which spread Islam, and have been traditionally proud of the urban, literate, and pious life with which this has been related. Both Wodaabe and other Fulbe see in the Wodaabe the echoes of an earlier pastoralist way of life, of which the Wodaabe are proud and of which urban Fulbe are sometimes critical.<ref name=beck1985 /><ref>Mette Bovin (2001), p.13</ref>
The Wodaabe culture is one of the 186 cultures of the [[standard cross-cultural sample]] used by anthropologists to compare cultural traits.
A Wodaabe woman, [[Hindou Oumarou Ibrahim]], was chosen to represent civil society of the world on the signing of [[2015 United Nations Climate Change Conference|Paris Protocol]] on 22 April 2016.<ref>[https://www.un.org/sustainabledevelopment/blog/2016/04/indigenous-mbororo-woman-to-speak-at-paris-agreement-signing-ceremony-on-22-april/ Indigenous Mbororo woman to speak at Paris Agreement signing ceremony on 22 April]. Sustainable Development Goals, United Nations. Retrieved on 15th June 2016.</ref>
==Everyday life== The Wodaabe keep herds of long-horned [[Zebu]] cattle. The dry season extends from October to May. Their annual travel during the wet season follows the rain from the south to the north.<ref>Gabrielle Lyon, [http://www.projectexploration.org/niger2000/wodaabe_feature_3.htm The Wodaabe]</ref> Groups of several dozen relatives, typically several brothers with their wives, children and elders, travel on foot, donkey or camel, and stay at each grazing spot for a couple of days. A large wooden bed is the most important possession of each family; when camping it is surrounded by some screens. The women also carry [[calabash]]es as a status symbol.<ref name=ng/> These calabashes are passed down through the generations, and often provoke rivalry between women. The Wodaabe mostly live on milk and ground [[millet]], as well as [[yogurt]], sweet tea and occasionally the meat of a goat or sheep.
==Religion, morals and customs== Wodaabe religion is largely but loosely [[Islam]]ic. Although there are varying degrees of orthodoxy exhibited, most adhere to at least some of the basic requirements of the religion.<ref name="africa.com">{{Cite web|url=http://www.gateway-africa.com/tribe/wodaabe_tribe.html|publisher="Africa.com"|title=Wodaabe religion}}</ref> Islam became a religion of importance among Wodaabe peoples during the 16th century when the scholar [[Muhammad al-Maghili|al-Maghili]] preached the teachings of [[Muhammad]] to the elite of northern Nigeria. Al-Maghili was responsible for converting the ruling classes among [[Hausa people|Hausa]], [[Fulani]], and [[Tuareg people|Tuareg]] peoples in the region.<ref name="Uiowa"/>
The code of behavior of the Wodaabe emphasizes reserve and modesty (''semteende''), patience and fortitude (''munyal''), care and forethought (''hakkilo''), and loyalty (''amana''). They also place great emphasis on beauty and charm.<ref>Beckwith, Carol, and Angela Fisher. ''African Ceremonies''. New York: Harry N Abrams, 1999.</ref>
Parents are not allowed to talk directly to their two first born children, who will often be cared for by their grandparents. During daylight, husband and wife cannot hold hands or speak in a personal manner with each other.<ref name=ng/>
[[File:1997 274-24 Gerewol.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Young suitors perform the ''Yaake'' dance in a [[Gerewol]] festival, Niger 1997]]
[[File:1997 276-18A Yaake demonstration.jpg|thumb|right|300px|A Yaake dance performed for tourists, Niger 1997]]
==Beauty ideal and Gerewol festival== {{Main|Gerewol}} At the end of the rainy season in September, Wodaabe clans gather in several traditional locations before the beginning of their dry season [[transhumance]] migration. The best known of these is [[In-Gall]]'s [[Cure Salee|Cure Salée]] salt market and [[Tuareg people|Tuareg]] seasonal festival. Here the young Wodaabe men, with elaborate make-up, feathers and other adornments, perform the ''Yaake'': dances and songs to impress marriageable women. The male beauty ideal of the Wodaabe stresses tallness, white eyes and teeth; the men will often roll their eyes and show their teeth to emphasize these characteristics. Wodaabe clans then join for the remainder of the week-long [[Gerewol]]: a series of barters over marriage and contests where the young men's beauty and skills are judged by young women.<ref>[http://travel.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/travel/destinations/africa/article453610.ece Niger's dandy Gerewol festival], ''[[The Times]]'', 4 July 2004</ref>
==Documentaries and popular culture== The 1989 documentary ''[[Wodaabe - Herdsmen of the Sun]]'' by [[Werner Herzog]] describes the Wodaabe.
In the 1999 documentary ''[[Zwischen 2 Welten]]'' (between two worlds) director Bettina Haasen films her personal conversations with Wodaabe members.
The 2010 ethnographic documentary [http://www.berkeleymedia.com/product/dance_with_the_wodaabes/ Dance with the Wodaabes] by Sandrine Loncke explores, from the point of view of its participants, the complex cultural significance of the spectacular but frequently misunderstood and sensationalized Wodaabe ritual celebrations known as "Geerewol".
The Niger-based band ''[[Etran Finatawa]]'' is composed of Wodaabe and [[Tuareg people|Tuareg]] members and creates their unique style of "Nomad Blues" by combining modern arrangements and electric guitars with more traditional instruments and polyphonic Wodaabe singing. In 2005 they recorded an album and toured Europe.
Married Wodaabe women are mentioned in part two of the BBC series ''[[Human Planet]]'' for having the right to take a different married man as a sexual partner.
"Wodaabe Dancer" is the name of an [[instrumental]] track on guitarist [[Jennifer Batten]]'s 1997 album, ''[[Jennifer Batten's Tribal Rage: Momentum]]''.
<gallery> Image:1997 275-15 young Wodaabe women.jpg|Young Wodaabe women with facial tattoos Image:1997 276-22A Wodaabe fashion.jpg|Two Wodaabe men Image:1997 275-9 Gerewol.jpg|A young woman judging the beauty of men at a Gerewol
</gallery>

{{Infobox ethnic group |group=Zimbabwean Australians |total=30,252 |popplace= [[Perth]], [[Sydney]], [[Melbourne]] |langs={{hlist|[[English language|English]]|[[Shona languages|Shona]]|[[Northern Ndebele language|Ndebele]]|[[Afrikaans]]|[[Chewa language|Nyanja]]}} |rels= |related=[[African Australians]] }} '''Zimbabwean Australians''' are Australian citizens who are fully or partially of Zimbabwean descent or [[Zimbabwe]]-born people who reside in Australia. They include migrants to [[Australia]] of people from [[Zimbabwe]] ([[Rhodesia]] until 1980), as well as their descendants. Today, over 30,000 people in Australia were born in Zimbabwe, while many more have Zimbabwean ancestry.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Zimbabwe-born Community|url=http://www.dss.gov.au/our-responsibilities/settlement-and-multicultural-affairs/programs-policy/a-multicultural-australia/programs-and-publications/community-information-summaries/the-zimbabwe-born-community|publisher=Department of Social Services}}</ref>
Australia's Zimbabwean community is now well established, with some of the highest incomes in the country,<ref>{{cite web|title=Irish among Australia’s best paid workers|url=http://www.irishecho.com.au/2013/06/13/irish-among-australias-best-paid-workers/26319|publisher=Irish Echo}}</ref> as well as with community institutions such as Zimbabwean language schools.<ref>{{cite web|title=Learning parents' language helps keep culture alive|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2015/07/29/learning-parents-language-helps-keep-culture-alive|publisher=SBS}}</ref>
==Background== [[File:ABS-3401.0-OverseasArrivalsDeparturesAustralia-PermanentMovementSettlers CountryBirthMajorGroupsSelectedSourceCountries-Original-NumberMovements-Zimbabwe-A83808782W.svg|thumb|right|300px|The number of permanent settlers arriving in Australia from Zimbabwe since 1991 (monthly)]]
The 2011 Census noted there are 30,252 Zimbabwe-born people living in Australia.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Zimbabwe-born Community|url=http://www.dss.gov.au/our-responsibilities/settlement-and-multicultural-affairs/programs-policy/a-multicultural-australia/programs-and-publications/community-information-summaries/the-zimbabwe-born-community|publisher=Department of Social Services}}</ref> The vast majority are skilled and educated, with 74.5% of the Zimbabwe-born aged 15 years and over possessing higher non-school qualifications, compared to 55.9% of the Australian population.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Zimbabwe-born Community|url=http://www.dss.gov.au/our-responsibilities/settlement-and-multicultural-affairs/programs-policy/a-multicultural-australia/programs-and-publications/community-information-summaries/the-zimbabwe-born-community|publisher=Department of Social Services}}</ref> Some Zimbabweans had originally moved to the UK, but decided to settle in Australia instead.<ref>{{cite web|title=Zimbabwe: First Family Has Low Opinion of the People|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201511290059.html|publisher=AllAfrica}}</ref>
==Population distribution== Australia's Zimbabwean population is biggest in [[Sydney]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ndlovu|first1=Ray|title=Rough estimates: Millions of Zimbabweans Abroad|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2013-04-19-millions-of-zimbabweans-abroad|publisher=AllAfrica|date=19 Apr 2013}}</ref> although a large proportion of Zimbabweans in Australia reside in [[Western Australia]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Zimbabwe-born Community|url=http://www.dss.gov.au/our-responsibilities/settlement-and-multicultural-affairs/programs-policy/a-multicultural-australia/programs-and-publications/community-information-summaries/the-zimbabwe-born-community|publisher=Department of Social Services}}</ref> Many [[White people in Zimbabwe|white Zimbabweans]] have settled in Queensland,<ref>{{cite web|title=White Zimbabwean families make their way to country Qld|url=http://www.abc.net.au/7.30/stories/s163928.htm|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation}}</ref> whereas people of indigenous [[Shona people|Shona]] and Ndebele ethnicities commonly settle in Sydney or Melbourne.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Zimbabwe-born Community|url=http://www.dss.gov.au/our-responsibilities/settlement-and-multicultural-affairs/programs-policy/a-multicultural-australia/programs-and-publications/community-information-summaries/the-zimbabwe-born-community|publisher=Department of Social Services}}</ref>
===Language===
====New South Wales==== Australians who speak a language indigenous to Zimbabwe at home are most numerous in Sydney. One in three of Australia's Ndebele-speakers and one in three of Australia's Shona-speakers live in Sydney.<ref>{{cite web|title=Languages in Sydney|url=http://www.censusdata.abs.gov.au/ABSNavigation/prenav/ViewData?action=404&documentproductno=105&documenttype=Details&order=1&tabname=Details&areacode=105&issue=2006&producttype=Census%20Tables&javascript=true&textversion=false&navmapdisplayed=true&breadcrumb=POLTD&&collection=Census&period=2006&productlabel=Language%20Spoken%20at%20Home%20(full%20classification%20list)%20by%20Sex&producttype=Census%20Tables&method=Place%20of%20Usual%20Residence&topic=Language&|publisher=Australian Burea of Statistics}}</ref><ref>[http://www.censusdata.abs.gov.au/ABSNavigation/prenav/ViewData?action=404&documentproductno=0&documenttype=Details&order=1&tabname=Details&areacode=0&issue=2006&producttype=Census%20Tables&javascript=true&textversion=false&navmapdisplayed=true&breadcrumb=POLTD&&collection=Census&period=2006&productlabel=Country%20of%20Birth%20of%20Person%20(full%20classification%20list)%20by%20Sex&producttype=Census%20Tables&method=Place%20of%20Usual%20Residence&topic=Birthplace&]</ref>
====Victoria==== English, Shona and Afrikaans are the main languages Zimbabwean Australians in Victoria speak at home. 53% of Zimbawean Australians in Victoria speak English, while 36% speak Shona and 1% speak Afrikaans.<ref>{{cite web|title=History of immigration from Zimbabwe|url=http://museumvictoria.com.au/origins/history.aspx?pid=226|publisher=Museum Victoria}}</ref>
